Article Title: Researchers on how China may be closing AI gap with the US
Article Text:
China bets on open-source software for AI development

Researchers and technologists have said that China is rapidly catching up to the US in the race for artificial intelligence (AI) development with a growing emphasis on open-source technology , a report has said.According to the New York Times, Chinese companies are sharing their AI advancements , including underlying code, through open-source platforms, allowing for faster collaboration and innovation within the global AI community .Recently at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference in Shanghai, a video was shown wherein an old photograph of a woman with two toddlers came to life with the use of AI technology similar to Sora ‚Äì created by ChatGPT-maker OpenAI .While Sora is not available for the public, the technology by Chinese companies are available to the general public.‚ÄúMy American friends still can‚Äôt use Sora. But we already have better solutions here,‚Äù the co-founder of the startup that made the AI video was quoted as saying.As per Kai-Fu Lee, an investor and technologist who helped build Chinese offices for both Google and Microsoft, and who co-founded 01.AI start-up, said that his company‚Äôs chatbot technology scored nearly as well as the leading American technologies on common benchmark tests that rate the performance of the world‚Äôs chatbots.‚ÄúWe have disproved the commonplace belief that China doesn‚Äôt have the talent or the technology to compete with the US. That belief is simply wrong,‚Äù Dr. Lee said.Chinese companies are readily sharing their AI advancements, including underlying code, through open-source platforms. This allows for faster collaboration and innovation within the global AI community.‚ÄúChinese companies are good at replicating and improving what the U.S. already has. They are not as good at inventing something completely new that will bypass the U.S. in five to 10 years,‚Äù said Yiran Chen, a professor of electrical and computer engineering at Duke University.Recently, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg pointed out that open-source AI software is beneficial for both the developers and the company. Cl√©ment Delangue, chief executive of Hugging Face also said that open-source AI is the foundation of AI development. He said that the US built its leadership in AI through collaboration between companies and researchers, ‚Äúand it looks like China could do the same thing.‚Äù

This allows for faster collaboration and innovation within the global AI community.‚ÄúWe have disproved the commonplace belief that China doesn‚Äôt have the talent or the technology to compete with the US. That belief is simply wrong,‚Äù Dr. Lee said.

Article Title: UK, EU question Elon Musk‚Äôs X over use of data to train Grok AI: What they said
Article Text:

How X‚Äôs auto-consent flouts tech rules in the UK, EU

Elon Musk-owned X recently enabled by default a setting that allows the social media platform to utilise user data to train its AI model, Grok. This means X can use user posts, interactions, and outputs from Grok for training and refining its AI, requiring users to manually opt-out. Now the regulators in the UK and the European Union ( EU ) have reportedly connected with the company over its alleged attempt to gain user consent for data harvesting without their approval.While X claims this data is essential for improving user experience, privacy concerns have been raised. The setting states that users ‚Äúallow your posts as well as your interactions, inputs and results with Grok to be used for training and fine-tuning‚Äù.Users have expressed difficulty in disabling this feature as the option is currently hidden within the web app's settings and unavailable on the mobile app.The move contradicts the tech laws in both the regions as the regulations prohibit pre-ticked consent boxes. Tech companies are not allowed to use ‚Äúpre-ticked boxes‚Äù or ‚Äúany other method of default consent‚Äù.Data protection authorities in the UK and Ireland have expressed their concerns over X's actions, as per a report by the Guardian. The UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) is investigating the matter, emphasising the importance of transparency and user choice in data usage.‚ÄúPlatforms seeking to use their users‚Äô data to train their AI foundation models must be transparent about their activities,‚Äù said a spokesperson for the ICO.‚ÄúThey should take steps to proactively notify users well in advance of using data for these purposes, and provide people with ample time and simple processes to object to having their data used in this way,‚Äù the spokesperson added.Similarly, Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC), the lead regulator for X in the EU, has expressed surprise at the development and is seeking further information from the company.‚ÄúThe DPC has been engaging with X on this matter for a number of months, with our latest interaction occurring as recently as yesterday, therefore we are surprised by today‚Äôs developments. We have followed up with X today (July 26) and are awaiting a response. We expect further engagement early next week,‚Äù said Graham Doyle, a DPC deputy commissioner.
Article Summary: X recently enabled by default a setting that allows the social media platform to utilise user data to train its AI model, Grok. This means X can use user posts, interactions, and outputs from Grok for training and refining its AI, requiring users to manually opt-out. Now the regulators in the UK and the European Union ( EU ) have reportedly connected with the company over its alleged attempt to gain user consent for data harvesting.

Article Title: Google fixes this ‚Äòdangerous‚Äô security flaw that allowed hackers to bypass email verification
Article Text:
‚ÄòFixed problem within 72 hours‚Äô

Google has said that it has fixed a security flaw that allowed hackers to bypass the company‚Äôs Email Verification to create potentially malicious Workspace Accounts and access third-party services.‚ÄúIn the last few weeks, we identified a small-scale abuse campaign whereby bad actors circumvented the email verification step in our account creation flow for Email Verified (EV) Google Workspace accounts using a specially constructed request,‚Äù a notice sent by Google to some users read.‚ÄúThese EV users could then be used to gain access to third-party applications using ‚ÄòSign In with Google‚Äô,‚Äù it added.In response to questions by known independent journalist Brian Krebs (via KrebsOnSecurity ), Google said it fixed the problem within 72 hours of discovering it. Anu Yamunan, director of abuse and safety protections at Google Workspace, said that the malicious activity began in late June.As per the company, ‚Äúa few thousand‚Äù Workspace accounts were created without being domain-verified. Google has added additional detection to protect against these types of authentication bypasses.‚ÄúThe tactic here was to create a specifically-constructed request by a bad actor to circumvent email verification during the signup process,‚Äù Yamunan was quoted as saying.‚ÄúThe vector here is they would use one email address to try to sign in, and a completely different email address to verify a token. Once they were email verified, in some cases we have seen them access third party services using Google single sign-on,‚Äù she said.As per Yamunan, no potentially malicious workspace accounts were used to abuse Google services.

Article Title: TikTok to soon roll out this YouTube Music-like feature
Article Text: TikTok , the popular short-video sharing platform, is making it even easier for users to discover new music. The app is rolling out a new feature that allows users to identify a song by simply singing or humming a tune.Dubbed " Sound Search ," the tool is designed to revolutionise the way users find and share music on the platform. With just a few notes, users can unlock a world of potential videos featuring the song they're looking for.TikTok's Sound Search is set to compete with established music identification apps like Shazam and SoundHound.However, the platform's unique focus on video content gives it a potential edge. Users can seamlessly transition from identifying a song to exploring a vast library of TikTok videos featuring that track.How it worksThe song identification tool works by analyzing the user‚Äôs vocal input and comparing it to a vast database of music. Once a match is found, the app provides information about the song, including the title, artist, and a link to the full track. Users can then add the song to their videos or explore more content related to the identified track. This seamless integration enhances the user experience by providing a direct path from song discovery to content creation.While the feature is currently in testing, it's expected to be widely available to users in the coming months. TikTok has yet to announce official launch dates or specific details about the tool's capabilities.As the feature continues to roll out, music lovers and TikTok creators alike are eagerly anticipating the potential impact on music discovery and sharing.
Article Summary: TikTok is rolling out a new feature that allows users to identify a song by simply singing or humming a tune. Dubbed Sound Search, the tool is designed to revolutionise the way users find and share music on the platform. Article Title: Olympics 2024: French cybercrimes team called in to 'protect' Israeli athletes after data leak
Article Text:
What data of Israeli athletes has been leaked online

Data including blood test results, login credentials and Israeli athletes' military status has been leaked. These details first appeared on a Telegram channel and then were reportedly leaded on other social media websites.

Israel foreign minister's 'warning'

French authorities are racing to protect Israeli athletes competing in the Paris Olympics after a wave of cyberattacks targeted their personal information. Sensitive data about Israeli athletes has been leaked online in what is believed to be a coordinated doxing attack. Publication of personal details online with malicious intent is called Doxing. The doxing activity was reported to Pharos , which is part of France's Anti-Cybercrime Office ( OFAC ).France's cybercrime unit OFAC is working to remove the compromised information from social media platforms. Israel has expressed deep concern over potential threats to its delegation and tourists during the Games, blaming Iran-backed groups for the increased risk. Israel's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, warned his French counterpart of the dangers posed by these organizations. "There are those who seek to harm the festivities of this joyous event," Foreign Minister Israel Katz told his French counterpart in a letter, copies of which were released to the media."We currently have assessments of potential threats from Iranian terror affiliates and other terrorist organisations aiming to carry out terror attacks against members of the Israeli delegation and Israeli tourists during the Olympics."In response, France has deployed a massive security force of 18,000 troops to safeguard the Olympics, which began on July 26 and will conclude on August 11.
Article Summary: Data including blood test results, login credentials and Israeli athletes' military status has been leaked. Israel has expressed deep concern over potential threats to its delegation and tourists during the Games. Israel's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, warned his French counterpart of the dangers posed by these organizations.

Article Title: India targets 100% village telecom connectivity in the next 12 months: Union minister Jyotiraditya M Scindia
Article Text: Union minister Jyotiraditya M Scindia said that the government aims for 100% village telecom connectivity within 12 months. The minister added that the government has allocated Rs 11,000 crore in the budget 2024-25 for flood management in Assam and Sikkim.Speaking at a press conference, Scindia, the Union minister for communications and development of north eastern region ( DoNER ), said ‚ÄúThe prime minister is committed to 100% saturation.We have identified around 24,000 villages in the country that still need saturation in terms of telecom connection.‚ÄùThe minister stated a special scheme has already been rolled out along with funds sanctioned for the purpose. Under the scheme, areas in the northeastern states are among these villages, and strategies are being worked out to reach these places.‚ÄúOne of the biggest problems in connectivity is terrain. Two things we are doing to resolve that, First provisions of the new telecom Act new rules for right to way we have circulated to give us access. Second one is a mix of technologies, some places we are using radio access networks, other places which are difficult to get we are using V-sat technologies and in more difficult places we may think of using satellites. Target of cent per cent saturation within 12 months across India‚Äù.He added, ‚ÄúI am monitoring this every week and by this we have connected 13,000 to 14,000 villages already. In the next 12 months or earlier we will complete the telecom saturation project.Provisions of the new telecom Act enable setting up required infrastructure and mixed technologies, like V-sat and satellite, are being utilised with the ‚Äútarget of cent per cent saturation within 12 months‚Äù, Scindia stated.‚ÄúI have been monitoring the work on a weekly basis, and 13,000-14,000 of these villages have also been covered,‚Äù he added. Scindia also spoke about the allocations for northeastern states in the 2024-25 Union Budget.
Article Summary: Jyotiraditya M Scindia said the government aims for 100% village telecom connectivity within 12 months. The minister added that the government has allocated Rs 11,000 crore in the budget 2024-25 for flood management in Assam and Sikkim. Under the scheme, areas in the northeastern states are among these villages.

Article Title: Elderly Bengaluru woman loses Rs 1.2 Crore in online scam: What exactly happened and how to stay safe
Article Text:
What exactly happened

Tips to protect yourself from online fraud

In yet another shocking incident of cyber fraud , a 77-year-old woman from Bengaluru has fallen victim to a scam, losing a staggering amount of Rs 1.2 crore. According to an online report, the elderly woman was duped by unknown fraudsters who managed to gain her trust and convince her to transfer the hefty sum.According to The Hindu, Lakshmi Shivakumar, the victim, received a phone call from an individual falsely claiming to be a Telecom Department official.The caller accused her of being involved in illegal activities through a SIM card allegedly purchased in her name in Mumbai. The caller further asserted that a complaint had been lodged with the Mumbai crime branch as per standard procedure.A few hours later, Shivakumar received calls from individuals identifying themselves as Sandeep Rao and Akash Kulhari, who claimed to be officers from the Mumbai Crime Branch. They accused her of money laundering involving a substantial sum of Rs. 60 crore. To verify her claims, the alleged officers demanded detailed information about her bank accounts and investments. They escalated the pressure by threatening arrest for non-cooperation and presented forged documents, including a purported FIR and Supreme Court arrest warrant.Following the disclosure of her personal financial information , Shivakumar was duped into transferring a substantial sum of Rs. 1,28,70,000 from her account. The scammers assured her that the money would be returned upon completion of the fabricated investigation.Following the investigation, Shivakumar patiently waited for its completion. However, when she attempted to contact the accused, they remained unreachable. Realising that she has been scammed, she then filed a police complaint.* Be wary of unsolicited calls and messages: Avoid sharing personal or financial information with unknown callers or through unverified links.* Verify the authenticity of requests: If you receive unexpected requests for money or personal details, cross-verify the information through official channels.* Install security software: Keep your devices protected with updated antivirus and anti-malware software.* Educate yourself: Stay informed about the latest cyber threats and scams by attending awareness programs or reading online resources.* Limit personal information online: Be cautious about sharing sensitive details on social media platforms.* Enable strong passwords: Use complex passwords for all online accounts and consider using two-factor authentication.* Regularly monitor bank accounts: Keep a close watch on your financial transactions and report any suspicious activity immediately.
Article Summary: A 77-year-old woman from Bengaluru has fallen victim to a scam, losing a staggering amount of Rs 1.2 crore. Lakshmi Shivakumar, the victim, received a phone call from an individual falsely claiming to be a Telecom Department official.

Article Title: Microsoft outage: CrowdStrike CEO explains the 'logic' that went wrong
Article Text:
The 'logic' that went wrong in CrowdStrike update

The machines impacted as per CrowdStrike

A faulty software update from US-based cybersecurity company CrowdStrike caused widespread disruptions on Friday, impacting critical services from airlines and banks to hospitals and stock exchanges. Millions of Microsoft Windows computers worldwide were rendered inoperable for several hours, and may across the world still continue to.In a blog post, CrowdStrike CEO George Kurtz, has explained what exactly may have caused the global outage.The post also shares a how-to guide for customers to fix the issue. There's also a root cause analysis. CrowdStrike emphasized that the incident was not a result of a cyberattack and that the issue has been resolved. Systems that downloaded the faulty update between 9:30 AM and 10:57 AM IST were most affected."On July 19, 2024 at 04:09 UTC, as part of ongoing operations, CrowdStrike released a sensor configuration update to Windows systems. Sensor configuration updates are an ongoing part of the protection mechanisms of the Falcon platform. This configuration update triggered a logic error resulting in a system crash and blue screen (BSOD) on impacted systems," wrote Kurtz.The CEO claimed that the issue has been rectified, "The sensor configuration update that caused the system crash was remediated on Friday, July 19, 2024 05:27 UTC.""Customers running Falcon sensor for Windows version 7.11 and above, that were online between Friday, July 19, 2024 04:09 UTC and Friday, July 19, 2024 05:27 UTC, may be impacted. Systems running Falcon sensor for Windows 7.11 and above that downloaded the updated configuration from 04:09 UTC to 05:27 UTC ‚Äì were susceptible to a system crash," said the blog post.
Article Summary: Faulty software update from US-based cybersecurity company CrowdStrike caused widespread disruptions on Friday. CrowdStrike emphasized that the incident was not a result of a cyberattack and that the issue has been resolved.

Article Title: WazirX suspends trading after $230 million loss: What 'India Ka Bitcoin Exchange' said on losing nearly half its reserves
Article Text:
Biggest Crypto hack in recent times

Hackers may have links to North Korea

WazirX, the leading Indian cryptocurrency exchange, has temporarily suspended all trading activities following a devastating cyberattack that drained nearly half of its reserves. The exchange that calls itself ' India Ka Bitcoin Exchange ' revealed in a post on X (formerly Twitter) on July 21 that hackers managed to steal approximately $230 million worth of crypto assets.The breach exploited a vulnerability in the exchange's multi-signature wallet system, compromising the security of stored funds. To mitigate further losses and ensure the protection of remaining assets, WazirX has temporarily halted customer withdrawals."Trading has been temporarily paused. The cyber attack theft has impacted our ability to maintain 1:1 collaterals with assets, and we've temporarily paused trading. We're conducting thorough forensic data examination and security audit procedures and working to enable withdrawals soon. User safety remains our top priority. Thank you for your patience and support during this challenging time. We will continue to provide regular updates üôè," read the post.Based on the Cyvers estimate, the amount lost from the multiple-signature wallet on WazirX would be one of the biggest crypto thefts in recent years and comes just a month after Japanese crypto exchange DMM Bitcoin lost over $300 million in a hackThe incident is said to have raised concerns about the exchange's security protocols and its ability to safeguard user funds. Some are also questioning WazirX's claim of maintaining a 1:1 collateral ratio with assets, sparking fears among investors about potential losses.In an attempt to recover the stolen funds, WazirX has launched a bounty program offering up to $23 million for information leading to the arrest of the culprits and the return of the stolen assets. Preliminary investigations by risk-management firm Elliptic suggest that the hackers may have links to North Korea.Elliptic said in a blog post that hackers affiliated with North Korea appear to have carried out the hack. ‚ÄúThe North Korea attribution is based on similarities in the types of services used by these hackers in the past, as well as similarities in their transactional behavior,‚Äù Tom Robinson, co-founder of Elliptic, said in an email.
Article Summary: WazirX, the leading Indian cryptocurrency exchange, has temporarily suspended all trading activities following a devastating cyberattack. The breach exploited a vulnerability in the exchange's multi-signature wallet system, compromising the security of stored funds. Preliminary investigations by risk-management firm Elliptic suggest that the hackers may have links to North Korea.
